intro: Neohymenopogon parasiticus, commonly known as the parasitic liverwort, is a species of liverwort that exhibits unique botanical characteristics. It is a non-vascular plant belonging to the family Pottiaceae, and it thrives in moist, shaded environments. The plant is distinguished by its small, closely packed leaves and a specialized structure called a pseudostele, which is a type of thallus. Neohymenopogon parasiticus is typically found growing on the bark of trees or on rocky surfaces. Its parasitic nature is reflected in its ability to derive nutrients from its host without a traditional root system.
